title: 111_s3065
content:
The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2010" aims to establish a policy of nondiscrimination based on sexual orientation in the Armed Forces by repealing the 1993 policy concerning homosexuality. The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2010" establishes a policy of nondiscrimination based on sexual orientation in the Armed Forces, prohibiting discrimination against any member or potential member based on sexual orientation. The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2010" prohibits discrimination in the Armed Forces based on sexual orientation, including actions such as promotion, demotion, evaluation, selection for awards, duty assignments, transfers, or separations. The Secretary of Defense and Secretary of Homeland Security cannot establish policies or take actions based on sexual orientation. The "Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2010" prohibits discrimination in the Armed Forces based on sexual orientation, including actions such as promotion, demotion, evaluation, selection for awards, duty assignments, transfers, or separations. The Secretary of Defense and Secretary of Homeland Security can prescribe regulations governing conduct without regard to sexual orientation. Re-accession into the armed forces is permitted for those separated based on sexual orientation if otherwise qualified. The term 'sexual orientation' in the Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2010 includes heterosexuality, homosexuality, or bisexuality, whether real or perceived, and covers consensual sexual conduct manifesting these orientations. The Military Readiness Enhancement Act of 2010 prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation in the armed forces. Amendments to Title 10 of the United States Code include adding protections against sexual orientation discrimination and updating references to gender-based and sexual orientation-based discrimination. Additionally, references to sexual orientation are added in various sections, and benefits are addressed in Section 5. SEC. 5. BENEFITS.

This Act does not require dependent benefits in violation of the Defense of Marriage Act.

SEC. 6. NO PRIVATE CAUSE OF ACTION FOR DAMAGES.

There is no private cause of action for damages under this Act.

SEC. 7. REVIEW AND IMPLEMENTATION. The Pentagon Working Group, established by the Secretary of Defense, makes recommendations on implementing the Act and its amendments. Existing working groups may be used for this purpose. Recommendations must be submitted to the Secretary of Defense within 270 days of the Act's enactment. The Pentagon Working Group must submit recommendations to the Secretary of Defense within 270 days of the Act's enactment. Within 60 days of receiving the recommendations, the Secretary of Defense must revise existing regulations and issue new ones to implement the Act and its amendments. The report must also be submitted to the Committees on Armed Services of the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Secretary of Defense must direct military departments to revise regulations within 120 days of receiving the report from the Pentagon Working Group. The revisions include adding sexual orientation nondiscrimination to equal opportunity policies and eliminating discriminatory personnel regulations. The Department of Defense and military departments are required to revise regulations to include sexual orientation discrimination in victims' advocacy programs and ensure personal conduct regulations are enforced without regard to sexual orientation. The term "sexual orientation" is defined in this section as per section 656(f) of title 10, United States Code. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 180 days assessing compliance of higher education institutions with a specific section of the United States Code regarding the Senior Reserve Officers' Training Corps. The report should detail any actions taken to deny funds to institutions that hinder the operation of the ROTC program.
